data.title: Stoute Hails Derby Win
data.meta_description: Twenty NINE years on from his first Derby success withShergar, Sir Michael Stoute was delighted by win No.5.
data.text:
Twenty NINE years on from his first Derby success withShergar, Sir Michael Stoute was delighted by win No.5.

On a blazing afternoon at Epson, Workforce stormed home in the calendar’s premier Classic.

The Freemason Lodge trainer watched his horse romp in seven lengths clear of 100-1 outsider At First Sight, rekindling memories of Shergar triumphing by a record 10 lengths in 1981.

“It’s one of the great feelings because it’s one of the great races, if not the greatest of them all,” said a delighted Stoute.

“Workforce won on his first time out, which was a run brimming with promise, but then he became a bit frustrating in the spring.

“This horse is a big fellow and when he threw a dirty scope in the early part of his build-up it put us behind schedule. But after his racecourse gallop atLingfield, I knew he was dead right for the Derby.”

Owner Prince Khalid Abdullah watched his silks carried to Derby glory for the first time since Commander In Chief in 1993 – and his racing manager Lord Grimthorpe said: “The prince is absolutely chuffed to bits.”

Stoute was loathe to compare Workforce with any of his other Derby winners, of which Shergar stands out as a very special colt.

It remains to be seen whether Workforce surpasses the heights reached by the remaining three: Shahrastani, Kris Kin and North Light.

Shergar went on to complete the Epsom Derby/Irish Derby double.

And Grimthorpe added: “You don’t have to be a clairvoyant to see the Irish Derby will be the next port of call.”

No bookies are betting on the Irish Derby but Workforce was cut from 33-1 into 6-1 for the Prix de l’Arc de Triomphe by Victor Chandler.
